comments.author: Jerry  English

comments.text:
Choose Life. Choose a job. Choose a career. Choose a family. Choose a 
fucking big television, choose washing machines, cars, compact disc players 
and electrical tin openers. Choose good health, low cholesterol, and dental 
insurance. Choose fixed interest mortgage repayments. Choose a starter 
home. Choose your friends. Choose leisurewear and matching luggage. Choose 
a three-piece suit on hire purchase in a range of fucking fabrics. Choose 
DIY and wondering who the fuck you are on Sunday morning. Choose sitting on 
that couch watching mind-numbing, spirit-crushing game shows, stuffing 
fucking junk food into your mouth. Choose rotting away at the end of it 
all, pissing your last in a miserable home, nothing more than an 
embarrassment to the selfish, fucked up brats you spawned to replace 
yourselves. Choose your future. #ChooseLife ... But why would I want to do 
a thing like that? I chose not to choose life. I chose somethin' else. And 
the reasons? There are no reasons. Who needs reasons when you've got heroin?
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Naf_WiEb9Qs﻿

comments.text:
Any Brit cinephile really should be happy that Danny Boyle came along and 
made British cinema cool. Danny Boyle is truly one of the most interesting 
directors working today, be it in the UK (I'd say he's the best out of 
there right now) or anywhere else. I feel British cinema before this 
focused too much on irony, dry humor and Hugh Grant to compete with 
American cinema, be it the best we gave or the worst. Dialogue was very 
much emphasized in this visual medium (not that there's anything wrong with 
that...I understand Britain's rich literary history). Then Boyle came along 
and gave us some of the best direction we would ever see from any film in 
that decade, taking the cool, visceral thrill of American pop-films (i.e. 
Tarantino) and showing that you guys don't need us. With Edgar Wright and 
many more coming after, Brit cinema has been a force to reckon with ever 
since.﻿
comments.author: Jem S

comments.text:
Opiods = selling your soul to the satan.

It’s the perfect mind and body altering substance.  If heaven isn’t as 
euphoric as a smack rush, then I don’t wanna be there.

It’s all so enchanting until you start waking up dry heaving and shitting 
liquid at the same time, drenching your bedsheets with sweat yet in a 
constant state of goosebumps and chills up the back of your neck, in 
unimaginable mental anguish and hopelessness – the most soul sucking 
depression of your life.  

Next thing you know you find yourself downing 100 pills of immodium of 
Immodium for just an iota of relief – or downing 5 pounds of culinary poppy 
seeds in the hopes of getting off on the most-oft nonexistent latex.  

Once you realize you need a fix to “get well”, you’re done.  Goodbye mate.  

For those of you using opioids for “fun” (not for intense pain that can’t 
be cured by NSAIDs or cannabis) – DON’T.  I have never met a soul who could 
use dope on a “recreational basis.”  Non-existent.  

“Who needs life when you’ve got heroin?”  THIS WILL BE YOUR MANTRA!

Whole nation-state’s populations of hundreds of millions have been enslaved 
by the poppy.  

I would encourage all of you to explore your INNER PSYCHE with LSD, 
Psilocybin, mesc, and of course cannabis.  

But touch anything deriving from the devil’s poppy and YOU ARE DONE!

Crack, coke, ethanol, etc - tried them all – none come close to the 
addictive power of the poppy.

In closing, dope feels absolutely heavenly, but will be back to collect its 
pound of flesh (as well as your soul).﻿
comments.author: workoutfanatic8777

comments.author: Michael Rooney

comments.text:
+christopher pesqueira Even when pain medicine is taken correctly, you will 
develop a tolerance. Your body adjusts and you will need more. How is that 
a miracle? Yes it is great for those who suffer a broken bone or may have 
terminal cancer but it is by no way miraculous to those with chronic pain. 
The only thing it does is cause a chronic pain sufferer to not experience a 
rebound effect when the opioid medicine is taken away. I doubt it has 
anything to do with "hanging" and more to do with the 
pharmaco-physiological makeup of the human central nervous system. This is 
something that no person can change, regardless of how much they believe 
they might. Eventually, everyone succumbs to dependence.
comments.author: Ryan K

comments.text: Where can I sell my soul for a life time supply?
comments.author: James Savel

comments.text:
The poppy is a plant. That's where the opioids come from. Yes it is hellish 
to people when addicted but it is also a "miracle" to those who suffer from 
pain. I suggest reading about the difference between drugs in general. You 
can't bunch up every drug together like the fool who believes about a war 
on drugs. The line between knowing and not knowing how substances effect 
you is very thin. Many can't hang but there are many more who can.  Usually 
these freak-outers are ignorant and who have deep set problems before their 
experimentation.
comments.author: christopher pesqueira

comments.text:
Both films are great. They approach similar subjects in radically different 
ways. Requiem for a Dream doesn't show the glamour of drugs, only the 
depressing aspects of drugs. Requiem for a Dream also doesn't try to be 
funny or upbeat. Requiem hit me harder but Trainspotting is a film one can 
actually "enjoy" watching.

comments.text:
Say... who removed me and Nancy from this film and why? And no, not 'that' 
Nancy, I'm talking about Nancy Sinatra. Oh, sure, I understand how you 
could be confused; happens all the time. But see, I can prove it... these 
here are Nancy's boots, authentic Westwoods! No way Vivian would ever let 
'that' Nancy wear her brand, plus 'that' Nancy was a flat-footed cow who 
would have never fit into these gorgeous boots! Now, I ask again... why 
were we removed from this film?

everything, if we're going to be responsible as adults we have to show them 
what does it mean and how it ends.
